diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect kidneys (nephritis), cause inflammation of the heart's outer layer (acute pericarditis), lead to pleural effusions, and potentially lead to neuropsychiatric manifestations that could present as delirium. Fever is also a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Infection of the heart valves can lead to acute pericarditis, fever, and may indirectly cause nephritis through immune complex deposition. It can also result in pleural effusions and systemic effects that might contribute to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.rationale: A severe and widespread infection that can cause fever, delirium (as part of septic encephalopathy), acute pericarditis, nephritis, and pleural effusions due to the systemic inflammatory response.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.rationale: A disease that can follow untreated strep throat or scarlet fever and can cause inflammation in various body parts, including the heart (pericarditis), joints, skin, brain (leading to delirium), and kidneys (nephritis). Fever and pleural effusion are also possible.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viruses (e.g., Coxsackievirus, HIV, influenza) can lead to acute pericarditis, nephritis, pleural effusions, delirium (particularly in severe cases or in the context of encephalitis), and fever.

diagnoses.name: Renal Failure
diagnoses.rationale: Severe acute or chronic renal failure can cause fluid overload leading to pleural effusions, pericarditis (uremic pericarditis), and fever. Delirium may occur due to the buildup of renal toxins affecting the brain.

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.rationale: The accumulation of waste products in the blood due to kidney dysfunction can cause uremic syndrome, which includes symptoms like pericarditis, pleural effusion, mental status changes (delirium), fever, and nephritis as part of the underlying kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis (TB)
diagnoses.rationale: TB can have diverse manifestations including fever, nephritis (renal TB), pleural effusion (pleural TB), pericarditis (TB pericarditis), and potentially delirium, especially in severe, disseminated disease.

diagnoses.name: Cancer
diagnoses.rationale: Certain cancers (e.g., lymphoma, lung cancer) can metastasize or directly involve structures leading to pleural effusions, cause nephritis (paraneoplastic syndrome), fever, acute pericarditis, and potentially delirium due to metabolic disturbances or brain metastases.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disease that can feature elements of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Patients may present with nephritis, pleural effusions, acute pericarditis, fever, and neuropsychiatric symptoms that could include delirium.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Hepatitis B or C with membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
Schizophrenia (for psychosis without a clear physical etiology)
Kidney disease related to systemic conditions

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Chronic inflammatory diseases (e.g., Rheumatoid arthritis, Systemic lupus erythematosus)

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Disorder
diagnoses.description: Disorders affecting the mechanism of blood clotting can lead to symptoms like epistaxis (nosebleeds) and could be associated with conditions like atherosclerosis indirectly. Hemorrhagic conditions could exacerbate or contribute to hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome (Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation; presents with recurrent epistaxis, and may have gastrointestinal bleeding presenting as diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, leading to increased levels of immature white blood cells. This can cause a wide range of symptoms including polycythemia, fatigue, and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels, which can cause atherosclerosis to worsen. Can lead to symptoms like epistaxis due to damage to small vessels and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, leading to symptoms like diarrhea. It can also cause systemic symptoms like hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Primary Polycythemia (Polycythemia Vera)
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder that leads to an increased level of red blood cells, which can cause a thickening of the blood and lead to symptoms such as epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Carcinoid Tumors
diagnoses.description: These are slow-growing tumors that can produce serotonin, leading to carcinoid syndrome which includes diarrhea among its symptoms. Flushing, a type of hypersensitivity reaction, may also occur.

diagnoses.name: Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: Diseases such as Lupus can cause widespread inflammation affecting many systems. Symptoms can include hypersensitivity reactions and vascular manifestations like atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Waldenström Macroglobulinemia
diagnoses.description: A rare type of cancer that produces excessive amounts of IgM antibody, leading to hyperviscosity syndrome which can explain the polycythemia and possible epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: Severe allergies can lead to hypersensitivity reactions. Allergies can also exacerbate other conditions like asthma, which doesn't directly relate to these symptoms but can be a complicating factor.

diagnoses: Squamous cell carcinoma of the mouth
Oral squamous cell carcinoma (due to leukoplakia)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: PANDAS/PANS (Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal Infections/Pediatric Acute-onset Neuropsychiatric Syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones.

diagnoses.name: Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: An infection of the air-filled space behind the eardrum (the middle ear).

diagnoses.name: Atherosclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which plaque builds up inside your arteries, leading to reduced blood flow.
common_treatments: Medications to lower cholesterol and blood pressure

diagnoses.name: Chronic Back Pain
diagnoses.description: A condition of persistent pain in the back, which can be caused by various factors including muscle or ligament strain, bulging or ruptured disks, and arthritis.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life.

diagnoses.name: Obesity
diagnoses.description: A disorder involving excessive body fat that increases the risk of health problems.
common_treatments: Weight loss surgery in severe cases

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the blood vessels have persistently raised pressure, putting them under increased stress.

diagnoses.name: Type 2 Diabetes
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose).

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts.

diagnoses.name: Polyphagia (Increased Appetite)
diagnoses.description: Excessive hunger or increased appetite and is one of the 3 main signs of diabetes.

diagnoses: Connective tissue diseases (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can lead to a weakened immune system, increasing susceptibility to infections. People with advanced HIV/AIDS may experience symptoms like leukoplakia in the mouth and unexplained fever (hyperthermia).

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: Certain types of leukemia can cause symptoms like fever (hyperthermia), increased susceptibility to infections due to low white blood cell count, and paleness or palpitations due to anemia. Leukoplakia can occasionally be related to a severely weakened immune system.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Iron deficiency anemia can cause symptoms like palpitations and bloating. It does not directly cause leukoplakia or increased susceptibility to infection, but severe cases can alter the immune system's effectiveness.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fever (hyperthermia), palpitations (due to associated anemia or heart involvement), and increased susceptibility to infections due to immunosuppression or medications used in treatment.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Lymphoma can present with symptoms like unexplained fever (hyperthermia), increased susceptibility to infections due to immune system compromise, and leukoplakia in advanced cases. Bloating might also occur if lymphoma affects abdominal organs.

diagnoses.name: Oral Squamous Cell Carcinoma
diagnoses.description: This type of oral cancer is directly associated with leukoplakia and can lead to systemic symptoms, including fever (hyperthermia) if there is an associated infection or advanced disease. It does not typically cause palpitations but might impact overall health status leading to symptoms like bloating.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the heart (causing palpitations), the lungs (increased susceptibility to infection), and can lead to fever (hyperthermia). Bloating can be a symptom if the gastrointestinal system is involved.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: Tuberculosis primarily affects the lungs but can have systemic symptoms including fever (hyperthermia), increased susceptibility to infections, and in advanced cases, leukoplakia can occur due to severe immune system impairment.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's Disease
diagnoses.description: Crohn's Disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can cause bloating and might lead to complications, including increased susceptibility to infections due to treatment or malnutrition. It does not typically cause leukoplakia or palpitations but can affect overall health.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic Kidney Disease can cause a wide array of symptoms, including increased susceptibility to infections, hyperthermia during infections, and palpitations due to associated anemia or electrolyte imbalances. It is less likely to cause leukoplakia or bloating directly.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting, occurring in response to a trigger, such as stress, pain, or seeing blood. It's characterized by sudden hypotension leading to reduced blood flow to the brain.

diagnoses.name: Orthostatic hypotension
diagnoses.description: A form of low blood pressure that happens when standing up from sitting or lying down, potentially causing fainting or dizziness, and could be related to dehydration or prolonged bed rest.

diagnoses.name: Addison's disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when your body produces insufficient amounts of certain hormones produced by your adrenal glands, leading to symptoms such as hypotension and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from excessive loss of body water, possibly due to high fever or vigorous exercise, leading to hypotension, syncope, and sometimes incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by diarrhea, cramps, nausea, vomiting, and often accompanied by muscle aches and fever that might cause hypotension and incontinence in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Toxic shock syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections. Symptoms may include sudden high fever, low blood pressure, vomiting or diarrhea, rash, and conjunctival injections.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly, leading to symptoms including hypotension, abdominal pain, incontinence, and conjunctival injections.

diagnoses.name: Seizure disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect the brain's electrical activity, which might cause unconsciousness and uncontrolled movements (potentially leading to incontinence), and may be associated with syncope.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A group of symptoms that occur when there is damage to nerves that regulate blood pressure, heart rate, bowel and bladder emptying, and digestion, potentially leading to hypotension, incontinence, and digestive symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Acute abdomen
diagnoses.description: An umbrella term for severe abdominal pain requiring immediate medical attention, potentially associated with various conditions such as appendicitis, ectopic pregnancy, or bowel obstruction. This syndrome may be accompanied by hypotension and syncope in severe cases.

diagnoses: Acute Abdominal Conditions (e.g., Acute Pancreatitis, Perforated Ulcer)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with lupus pneumonitis
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or Ulcerative colitis) with extraintestinal manifestations
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation with associated infection
Heart failure with acute pulmonary edema
Primary Angiitis of the Central Nervous System

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden weakness, numbness, difficulty speaking, confusion, trouble seeing, dizziness, or loss of balance.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision, and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant). Symptoms can include headaches, changes in speech or hearing, balance and coordination issues, as well as weakness or numbness on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Ménière's Disease
diagnoses.description: Ménière's disease is a disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In most cases, Ménière's disease affects only one ear. It can cause sudden episodes of vertigo, along with ringing in the ear (tinnitus) and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A noncancerous and usually slow-growing tumor that develops on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Branches of this nerve directly influence balance and hearing. Symptoms may include hearing loss, ringing in the ear, dizziness, and loss of balance.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a brief interruption of blood flow to part of the brain, spinal cord, or retina, which may cause temporary stroke-like symptoms like aphasia, numbness, weakness, or dizziness.

diagnoses.name: Labyrinthitis
diagnoses.description: An inner ear infection or inflammation that affects the nerves in the inner ear responsible for balance and hearing. Symptoms can include vertigo, hearing loss, and difficulty focusing the eyes.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes tumors to form on nerve tissue. These tumors can develop anywhere in your nervous system, including your brain, spinal cord, and nerves. Symptoms are variable and can include hearing loss, weakness, and balance issues.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from the reduction of blood flow to the back part of the brain, which is supplied by the vertebral and basilar arteries. Symptoms can include vertigo, dizziness, double vision, slurred speech, and imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease
diagnoses.description: An uncommon condition that causes progressive hearing loss and vertigo. It's thought to occur when the body's immune system attacks the inner ear by mistake. Symptoms can include rapidly progressive hearing loss, vertigo, and tinnitus.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Viral Infections (such as Epstein-Barr Virus, Cytomegalovirus)
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
